Gary wasn't very good at school, but he shone in the kitchen. By the time he was 15, he was as good as the other chefs, and sometimes he was even left in charge. He could produce over 100 meals, and I knew he would go into catering.

Gary recently started playing the drums and has his own band. I told him that if he chases two goals, he might not achieve either. He understood when I said he needs to focus on one thing to be successful. Gary went to catering college at 17 and was given a lot of work to do on his first day. But he finished everything quickly and was helping others. I'm very proud of him. He's worked hard for his success, and I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work for it.

Here is the simplified text for a B2 level learner:

Dolphins are loved by many people. We enjoy watching them in marinas, films, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their situation is very serious. Dolphins are highly intelligent and sensitive to human emotions. They are often shown in a positive light in the media, such as in films like Flipper and Darwin in Seaquest. However, this does not reflect the reality of their lives in the polluted and overfished seas of the late 20th century.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises has been reduced by up to 89,000. You might expect these popular animals to be protected by law and kept safe in marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and the lack of plans to protect them could become one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are 40 different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In European waters, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoise dolphins. The striped and common dolphins live far out at sea and are rarely seen. The bottlenose and harbour porpoise dolphins were once common near European coasts, but now they are mostly found in Scotland and Wales. Unfortunately, the few remaining bottlenose dolphins are showing signs of stress.

It is difficult to determine the exact reasons for the decline in dolphin numbers. Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks worldwide and threatening local fishing industries, is also harming porpoises and dolphins. Dolphins need to find food quickly, so if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive. They are also at risk of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which can be invisible to them.

In recent years, hundreds of dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornish beaches, showing that they were caught in these nets. Dolphins can also store waste and other substances in their bodies, such as pesticides, which can be passed on to their young through their milk. There is already one recorded case of a young dolphin being poisoned and killed by its mother's milk.

Another threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and communicate through sound. Noise pollution from ships, oil wells, and other sources can disturb them in ways we do not yet understand.

I made minimal changes to the factual content to ensure that the text remains answerable, while simplifying the language to a B2 level.<|eot_id|>

EXERCISE IS GOOD FOR YOU Exercise is essential for our overall well-being. It helps us stay balanced in a world that is often fast-paced and chaotic. There are many reasons why exercise is good for us, and few reasons why we shouldn't do it. Regular exercise can improve our physical appearance, increase our muscle power, and help us maintain good posture. It can also prevent injuries and improve our heart and lung function. Exercise can even help us feel less stressed, improve our sleep, and ease depression and tiredness.

In addition, exercise can help manage certain medical conditions. There are many types of exercise we can do, such as aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, and weightlifting. However, it's important to start slowly and carefully to avoid injury. If you're unsure, it's a good idea to consult with a doctor.

Good posture is also essential. If we have good posture, we will look and feel better. It's like having a helium balloon attached to the top of our head, lifting us up and making us stand taller. Stretching exercises can also improve our flexibility and prevent injuries.

To get the most out of exercise, it's important to follow a routine that includes a warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period. By following these steps, we can achieve a more flexible and fitter body.

Their daily routine involves setting up camp and making tea the night before. They eat pre-packed meals, which can be a challenge when they are away for up to eight weeks at a time. Despite the challenges, they enjoy being in remote areas, where they can get close to the animals and become part of their lives.

Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, got a job offer on the spot, but reacted too enthusiastically, which led to a lower salary. Finally, it's crucial to prepare for an interview by researching the company and having a few questions ready. Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests speaking in short sentences and using highlighted points to communicate effectively.'

Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives

A Darius (runner) I've always been into sports. I played a bit of everything, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a chance to try out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and getting a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I was hoping for some sponsorship. I train at home during the winter and then go away for three weeks before the season starts. It's a lot of hard work, but it's worth it. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics.

B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you see the same people everywhere you compete. Professional surfers are very serious and often the best waves are at dawn, so you have to be disciplined. I don't mind giving up late nights, but I do love sleeping in. It's worth it because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships. After a big win, I like to celebrate with a big night out. And, of course, the sacrifices are worth it in the long run because winning the championship meant I got to present a surfing series on TV. I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

C Dieter (yacht racer) With five friends on a boat, we always have a good time. We're a traditional group and we celebrate our wins in style. We don't seek out media attention, but sometimes reporters are more interested in where we go out and what we do there than in our sailing results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's great to get back and do normal things with my friends. You can't live and breathe sailing all the time ‚Äì it's not healthy. I'm known in the sailing world, but I'm lucky to be recognized in the street only a few times. I reply to every letter I get from fans, even if it takes a while.

D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd's support. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around, but I still get a thrill when fans recognize me outside of competitions. However, it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. As a tennis player, you have to travel a lot, and that's why we split up. You have to make sacrifices in any sport, but I'm okay with that. I'm focused on my game now and will catch up on other things in life when I retire, which is not far off in this sport.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B2:

Shopping with children can be very challenging. One mother says that her children always want everything they see, including the latest sugary cereals, Disney videos, and comics. She finds it difficult to say no to their demands and feels guilty about buying unhealthy food. At the same time, she hates herself for not being able to say no all the time and gets defensive when they go shopping. She tries to avoid taking them shopping, but then worries that she is not giving them the chance to make their own choices.

Research shows that children make a purchase request every two minutes when they are taken shopping. In fact, more than ¬£150 million is spent on advertising directly to children every year, mostly on television. This figure is likely to increase, and it is in the supermarket aisles that the advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't afford certain things, and arguments about the negative effects of sugar are not convincing when compared to attractive and emotional advertising campaigns.

According to Susan Dibb of the National Food Alliance, most parents are concerned about what they feed their children and have their own ideas about healthy food. However, these ideas are not always accurate. Parents resent the fact that they are competing with the advertising industry and are forced to repeatedly disappoint their children.

The Independent Television Commission regulates TV advertising and prohibits advertisers from telling children to ask their parents to buy products. However, the purpose of advertising is to persuade people to buy something, so even if they don't directly ask children to buy something, the intention is still to influence them.

Some parents find it stressful to decide which demands to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says that she is patient when discussing food with her children, but still feels unhappy about the way she handles their shopping demands. Another mother has taught her son to be critical of advertisements and they spend time looking at labels together. They rarely have conflicts in the supermarket because the children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents also admit that they are inconsistent and sometimes hypocritical in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says that they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they are bad for him, but they buy chocolate and double cream for themselves. He finds it hard to be consistent and sometimes gives in to his children's demands.

Supermarkets could do more to ease parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less because their children are not with them, the thought of shopping without their children's demands would likely attract enough extra customers to make up for the difference.<|eot_id|>

**Ice Skating: A Fun and Challenging Sport**

Ice skating has a long history that dates back thousands of years. The first skates were made from animal bones. People used these skates until iron became widely available in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In the past, skating was a popular activity among the upper classes, and it was considered an essential skill.

In the early 20th century, skating was a stylish and exclusive activity. However, the 1924 Winter Olympics introduced a new, more athletic approach to the sport, which increased its popularity. Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism, requiring both grace and physical fitness.

To start skating, it's essential to focus on balance and control. Beginners should keep their body weight centered by bending their knees and leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is also crucial, as it helps to reduce the risk of injury. To get started, stand with your heels almost touching and your feet turned outwards. Move your back foot forward while making a small movement with your other foot.

It's normal to fall while learning to skate, but it's essential to know how to fall safely. To avoid injury, stay relaxed and try to roll with the fall. When you get up, use your hands to help you get into a kneeling position and then stand up.

Once you're comfortable moving on the ice, you can try different styles, such as figure skating, freestyle, and speed skating. However, it's recommended to start with figure skating and then move on to freestyle. Most ice rinks offer lessons and guidance to help you learn the basics and improve your skills.

To become a good skater, it's essential to practice regularly and include exercises in your routine to improve your balance, flexibility, and strength. Skating can also help improve your overall health and fitness, especially when combined with other activities like swimming or jogging.<|eot_id|>

She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete in the Olympics. 'I have to work very hard. I don't have time for TV, friends, or many other activities. I focus on training and school. Shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it ‚Äì I love it. Even if my parents weren't involved, I would still do it because I'm determined. My goal is to qualify for the British young riders team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal.'

'Are we getting too big for our boots? Chris Greener, the tallest man in Britain, is 228 cm tall. He's not alone - the average height of people in Europe is increasing by one centimetre every decade. This means that more people are growing taller, but it's not because we're producing a new super race. Instead, we're returning to what our ancestors were like thousands of years ago. In fact, we're becoming like the people who lived during the Stone Age, 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods, including fruits, vegetables, and meat. They had a healthy diet and were well-nourished. But around 9,000 years ago, people started farming, and this had a negative impact on our health. We began to eat more carbohydrates, such as wheat, rice, and maize, and this led to a decline in our overall health and physique.

In some parts of the world, people who used to be healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly and underweight when they started farming. Tooth decay and diseases increased, and many people suffered from malnutrition. It wasn't until recently that people in wealthier countries started to eat a more balanced diet again.

As a result, the average height of people in some countries has increased. In the US, the average height is 179 cm, in Holland it's 180 cm, and in Japan it's 177 cm. However, this trend has its own problems. For example, beds and furniture are still the same size they were 150 years ago, and clothes manufacturers have to constantly update their ranges to accommodate the taller population.

The question is, how tall can we get? Some scientists think that our maximum height could be as much as 193 cm, but others believe that we may be reaching a limit. And there's another factor to consider - global warming. As the planet warms up, we may actually start to shrink again. So, the growth of human beings could be offset by climate change.'

For others, it's a chance to be part of something special and feel like they're involved in the show. One person I talked to said that seeing her favorite comedian live was more exciting than watching him on TV at home. Of course, there are some downsides to being in a studio audience. The seats can be uncomfortable, and you might not always be able to see what's happening on stage. But for many people, the experience is worth it.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We're a family who loves animals. One day, my daughter called me at work with exciting news. She had found a beautiful pine snake. "Can we keep it?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for a night." We had a special tank for temporary pets, and I thought it would be a fun experience for the kids to learn about snakes.

When I got home, I was in a hurry. I was making dinner when my sons came running into the kitchen, screaming, "Mum, help! The cat is attacking the mouse!" I rushed into the bedroom to find Domino the cat chasing Bianca the white mouse. Domino had caught the mouse and was running around the room, trying to get away from the kids. I tried to catch Domino, but I tripped and fell. As I got up, I saw the snake had escaped from its tank. It was slithering across the floor, and the kids were jumping over it, screaming and laughing.

I tried to catch the snake, but it was hard. It kept striking at me, and I was worried it might hurt someone. Finally, I managed to grab the snake and put it in a safe place. The cat and mouse were still causing chaos, so I had to intervene again. After a few tries, I managed to catch the cat and free the mouse.

The snake was very slippery and hard to handle, but I eventually managed to sit down with it and calm it down. I looked for a weak spot to release it, but it didn't have any. I decided to let it go in the garden, pointing it towards a tree. To my surprise, it wrapped itself around my shoulders and seemed to be making itself comfortable for the winter.

The kids and I stood there in silence for a moment, then my oldest son broke the silence with a scientific explanation: "You're nice and warm, Mum, and the shed isn't." I encouraged the kids to gently guide the snake towards the wall, and it slowly slid away, disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of tail disappeared, my three-year-old son sighed and said, "That was a big snake!"

I have penfriends in Sri Lanka, Australia, and Canada, and I've even made friends through letters. Now, we have a regular correspondence, and I've even been able to improve my French. I'm grateful that my children are carrying on the tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little notes, just like I used to write to my mother. And my son has penfriends in Texas, thanks to my penfriend. I urge everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.'

Many of these early walls were inspired by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He developed the idea of setting natural rock into a concrete block, which could be included in a wall. Scores of climbing walls were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s. However, these walls had limitations. They could only be built vertically, unlike cliffs, which have features like overhangs and angled rock. Once the walls were built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored. In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny developed a material that could be molded into shapes like those found on cliffs. These shapes could be attached to any existing wall and removed when climbers got bored. French manufacturers also experimented with steel frames and interchangeable fixtures, allowing for endless combinations of holds.'

Do you want to become an actor? If you do, you'll likely hear people say that acting is a risky career. And it's true - there are more people who want to be actors than there are acting roles available. When you decide to pursue a career in acting, some people who were your friends will think you're crazy, while others will give you different advice. Ultimately, it's a personal choice, and you're responsible for your own success or failure.

There's no easy way to become an actor - no exams to pass or guarantees of success. It's a matter of luck, talent, and hard work. But there is a demand for new faces and new talent, and the possibility of excitement, glamour, and financial rewards.

So, what is talent? I think it's a combination of natural ability and imagination. Imagination is the most difficult quality to assess, and it's closely linked to an actor's courage and confidence in their work.

Where does the desire to act come from? It's often hard to explain why you want to act, but for many actors, it's about that special moment when they connect with an audience. This connection is central to all acting, whether it's on stage or screen.

When asked how they've succeeded in their careers, actors often shrug and say they don't know. They know certain things about themselves and their craft, but they never take anything for granted, because they know they're only as good as their current job, and their fame can be fleeting. Disappointment is the biggest enemy of an actor.

Actors often don't talk about their chances of getting a part, as they know that rejection is a possibility from the start. They develop coping mechanisms to deal with the stress of auditioning and the possibility of rejection. No one likes being rejected, and it's up to each individual to care enough to make it happen.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B2:

It's true that we're getting taller. Chris Greener, who is now Britain's tallest man, was only 14 when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. His teacher asked him what he wanted to be, and Chris replied, 'The flagpole on a ship.' This was because Chris was already very tall, at 228 cm. Today, people in Europe are getting taller by about 1 cm every 10 years. More and more people are born who are very tall. However, this doesn't mean we're becoming a super race. In fact, we're returning to what our ancestors were like 40,000 years ago. Professor Chris Stringer, a scientist, says we're becoming like the Cro-Magnons, who lived on this planet a long time ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from many different sources. They ate a variety of plants and animals. Then, about 9,000 years ago, people started farming. This had a big impact on the environment and our diet. Today, most people eat a diet based on just three types of carbohydrate-rich foods: wheat, rice, and maize. This diet has had negative effects on our health and physique. In one study, scientists found that when people started eating corn, they became sickly and underweight.

In the past, people were not well-nourished and were stunted. This is only recently being addressed, even in wealthy countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, people are now eating a more varied diet, and this is reflected in their height. The average height in these countries is now 179-180 cm. However, this trend also has its own problems. For example, beds and furniture are still the same size as they were 150 years ago, and clothes manufacturers have to constantly update their products.

The question is, how tall can we get? Will we continue to grow indefinitely? Some scientists think we may reach a maximum height of 193 cm this century. However, others point out that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, our ancestors were slightly taller and rounder because of the cold. Since the climate warmed up, we've become slightly thinner and smaller. And as the planet continues to warm up, we may shrink even further. This means that the growth of human beings could be offset by global warming.

'Confident people: what's their secret? Confident people may seem like they've always been that way, but most will tell you that it's a skill they've learned. We asked five people how they did it.

A Jenny: When I left school, I was very shy. I was 25 when I started helping out at my daughter's school. I was nervous, but I surprised myself by doing well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was scared at first, but my confidence grew as I became more outgoing. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

B Michaela: Four years ago, my father got ill and I had to take over the family business. I was scared, so I became a bit too bossy and impatient. I thought that's what confident people were like, but I learned otherwise. To be confident, you have to believe in yourself. When things get tough, I don't feel guilty about putting off tasks until the next day. When I'm faced with something difficult, I tell myself I have nothing to lose.

C Lisa: People think I'm confident, but I'm actually really nervous. I've learned to look confident because it's important in my job. Interviewing people has shown me that most of us get nervous in important situations. I feel calmer when I talk to someone who is friendly. The best advice I got was from my mother: "Who's looking at you? Everyone's too busy worrying about themselves."

D Barbara: My confidence comes from enjoying my work. I've built it up over the years. If you learn from your mistakes, you'll be more confident next time. I work hard and people like me, but I know that not everyone will. You have to like yourself for who you are, not try to be someone else.

E Kim: After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak up in meetings. Eventually, I found the courage to express my opinions. Even when I started working in politics, I was nervous about speaking in public. I told myself, "Don't be silly. People do this every day, so why can't I?" I also wrote down a few points to refer to, like having a security blanket. I don't think anyone is completely confident when speaking in public. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."'

I visited Malaysia to attend a kite-flying festival. I met Adnan Ali, a local, who showed me his collection of intricately decorated kites. We sat under the trees and watched the festival, where competitors were waiting for the countdown to release their kites. The festival takes place every year for five days and attracts over 500 participants. Each participant enters four different kite designs, which are judged on decoration, stability, and flying efficiency.

Adnan invited me to visit him at his home to learn how to make kites. I accepted and spent the evening drinking tea and eating snacks in his large, polished room. However, I had to leave the next day and explore the state. I drove inland towards Kuala Lumpur, but took a wrong turn and ended up at a river. I took a boat to the other side and saw a sign pointing to a jungle track. I decided to follow it and met Baba, who was running a tented kitchen and huts. I stayed there for the night, despite the creepy sounds and insects.

The next morning, I woke up to a stunning view of the mountains. Later, it rained, and I got wet. I slid down the track and was relieved to find my car still there, covered in mud. When I returned to the city, people asked me many questions, but they were all friendly. I remember my trip more for the kindness of the people than the kites.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but some people love it, while others hate it. Abby Edwards asked some friends about their shopping habits. Here's what they said:

A. Melanie, a 22-year-old dancer, is an addict. She loves shopping and spends a lot of money. She even drags her boyfriend around the shops with her.

B. Brenda, a 40-year-old office manager, is a reluctant shopper. She doesn't enjoy shopping for clothes and often feels guilty when she does buy something. She usually doesn't tell her husband how much she's spent.

C. Juliet, a 28-year-old personnel manager, only shops for essentials. She hates shopping and finds it tiring. She knows what she wants and won't settle for anything else.

D. Anita, a 35-year-old TV producer, likes to shop, but she knows what she wants and gets in and out quickly. She sometimes buys things that don't quite fit, but she doesn't mind.

E. Lizzie, a 41-year-old secretary, dislikes shopping. She finds it stressful and usually only goes shopping for food. She rarely has to buy clothes, as most of hers are given to her.

F. Lisa, a 22-year-old actress, is a happy shopper. She enjoys going out with her friends and sometimes buys things on impulse.

G. Suki, a 26-year-old art gallery assistant, is a careful shopper. She likes going to the shops, but she doesn't buy much. She sometimes shops to cheer herself up, but often feels worse afterwards.

H. Ann-Marie, a 29-year-old nursery worker, loves shopping, but only on certain days. She's a careful shopper and likes to compare prices before buying something.

I. Linda, a 32-year-old restaurant manager, is an unwilling shopper. She only goes shopping when she has to, and doesn't like trying things on. She's not too bothered if the clothes don't fit.

'Money What is money? Money is not just a pound, dollar, or franc. It's like a gram or a kilometre - you can exchange it for something else. A five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs almost nothing to make. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do now. They didn't have banks or shops. In those days, farmers would exchange their crops for honey with other farmers. This was a direct exchange between two people, each with something the other wanted. Later, societies created their own systems of exchange, which is why we have national currencies today. Over time, these currencies have joined together, which is why we use national currencies now.'

Hypatia: The First Woman Scientist

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 AD. For a long time, she was the only woman scientist to be remembered in history books. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he made sure she had the best education possible. This was unusual, as most women at that time had limited opportunities to study.

Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome before returning to Alexandria, where she began teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. Although we don't have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to help with her work.

However, many rulers at that time were afraid of science, and anyone connected with it was in danger. Unfortunately, Hypatia's life was cut short when she was attacked and killed in the street in March 415.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B2:

Climbing Ben Nevis in Scotland Each year, many people climb Ben Nevis, the highest mountain in Britain. It's a challenging climb, especially in winter when the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt describes his first winter climb on Ben Nevis. We climbed the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It's a long climb, about 600 meters high. We planned to camp for three days at the 'Carries', which are natural bowls in the mountain half-way up. We took our tents, sleeping bags, and special spikes for our boots, as the snow was very hard and icy. Even though some of the group were experienced climbers, we took all the necessary safety equipment, including lights, hard hats, and extra clothing. Although the weather forecast was good, we still felt a bit nervous when we started. Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The track got steeper and my legs felt heavy. As the weakest member of the group, I had to rest more often. The others would stop to let me catch up, but then they would start again. I promised myself to train better before my next climb. After 200 meters, we reached the beginning of Tower Ridge, the route to the top of Ben Nevis. It's very narrow, only 1.5 meters wide, and the mountain drops away on both sides. We had to stay calm and focused as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye 48 kilometers away. Unfortunately, we didn't have a clear view because of the mist. Climbing down Ben Nevis can be just as challenging as climbing up. You need to be able to read a map correctly to avoid taking a wrong turn, which could be dangerous in winter. I was relieved that we took turns to navigate. Only when I was safely in my tent did I really feel like I had enjoyed the experience. At least I made it to the top.

For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in the winter, the area was quiet and peaceful. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to create an art exhibition in a special igloo in the town of Jukkasjarvi. The exhibition was a success, and some visitors had the idea to sleep in the igloo. They enjoyed their experience so much that the idea of building an ice hotel was born.

Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world. Every winter, a team of experts from all over the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They work on different parts of the hotel, and each part is opened to visitors and guests as it is finished. The hotel is built using natural materials like snow and ice, so the finishing date depends on the weather.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5¬∞C to -8¬∞C, even when it's very cold outside. Guests are provided with warm clothing like overalls, hats, and gloves. It's also a good idea to bring your own warm clothing and thick socks. You can buy the necessary clothing and equipment on the ICEHOTEL website when you book your visit.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, near the Arctic Circle. It's close to Kiruna airport and train station, and you can take a bus from there to the hotel.

Tanya Streeter is a world-renowned free-diver. She holds four world records in this sport, where competitors dive to great depths on a single breath. In 2003, Tanya made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters into the ocean without breathing and return to the surface on her own. She had gone deeper before, but on that occasion, she used a balloon to get back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the only woman to break a world record set by a man. A team of 14 safety divers watched her dive from different depths.

Some people think free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya believes safety is the most important thing, followed closely by proper training. Most free-divers specialize in one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine is the same regardless of what she's preparing for. Two-thirds of her training is done on land, at the gym, and the rest is divided between the pool and the ocean. She also uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness. However, she avoids running because she doesn't want to risk injuring her knees. Instead, she finds that fast walking is an effective way to build her fitness.

When Tanya is preparing for an event, she usually travels away from home and does 14 dives over a four-week period, with a rest day in between each dive. It's essential that she doesn't get tired, as that could ruin all her preparation. When she's not preparing for an event, she makes public appearances to promote sports products and support environmental organizations. She has also done research projects and made films.

Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, where she spent her childhood swimming and exploring rock pools to watch the sea life. She says her life today is like living her childhood dreams. As a well-known figure in some countries, she believes people are willing to listen to her when she talks about environmental issues. For the future, Tanya plans to continue breaking her own world records. Although she started free-diving at 25, she doesn't intend to retire from the sport for many years to come.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level B2:

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every year, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, turns into a kaleidoscope of colours. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event. The festival started in 1972 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of a local radio station. At first, there were only a dozen hot-air balloons, but it has grown into a massive event. This year, over a thousand balloons from around the world are expected to attend. What to see

The pilots communicate with each other and simultaneously light up their burners, creating a spectacular sight called a 'balloon glow'. To see this, you need to arrive just after sunset or before 5:30 am. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in all shapes and sizes, including animals, cartoon characters, and well-known brands. Kids will love it.

In the afternoon, you can take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies offering flights. Alternatively, you can take a cable car to the top of the nearby mountains and enjoy a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are many other activities for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and firework displays on the opening and last three evenings of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

The unique wind pattern in this area, known as the Albuquerque Box, makes it an ideal location for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

Practical advice

Buy your tickets in advance to avoid long queues. Wear layers of thin clothing, as it can be cool at night and early morning, but hot during the day. Bring a flashlight for night-time events and a camera to capture the stunning views. If you're not using a digital camera, bring high-speed film for evening and night-time photos.<|eot_id|>

THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD

In the 1880s, gold was discovered in Alaska, a state in the USA. Many people moved to the area to search for gold. A town called Iditarod grew quickly and became the largest city in Alaska for a short time. In the winter, it was difficult to deliver supplies to the town because the rivers and ocean froze. So, a special winter road was built for dog sleds to transport goods, such as mail, food, and clothes, to the gold miners. This road was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for the dogs to travel across Alaska. The drivers would stop at special houses called roadhouses to rest and feed themselves and their dogs.

The Iditarod Trail was used every winter until the 1920s, when airplanes became the main way to travel. However, in 1925, a serious illness called diphtheria broke out in the city of Nome. The medicine to cure the disease was in Anchorage, but it was too far away to reach by air. So, a team of dogs was used to transport the medicine. The journey was over 1,000 kilometers long and took six days to complete. A Norwegian man named Leonhard Seppala and his dog Togo led the way for the first 400 kilometers. The rest of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen and his lead dog Saito. At one point, another dog named Balto refused to go further and saved the team from falling into icy water. Balto became a hero and helped stop the spread of the disease.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as that famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth".<|eot_id|>

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights**

Welcome to our website! Before booking a flight, please read the following information.

We take tourists on a 12-hour flight over Antarctica using a Boeing 747 plane. The flight is divided into three parts: four hours over the sea, four hours over Antarctica, and four hours back to Sydney. On the way, our experts will talk about the environment and history of Antarctica, and answer your questions. You'll also have a camera view of the pilot's seat, giving you a unique perspective of the flight.

**Seat Allocation**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point, you'll move to the seat shown on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half the flight and a next-to-window seat for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half the flight and an end-of-row seat for the other half.

**Flight Changes**

We have 17 approved flight plans to ensure the best views. Our captain chooses the best route based on satellite cloud pictures on the morning of the flight.

**Wildlife**

Unfortunately, we can't see Antarctic wildlife in detail as most animals live at sea level, 3,000 meters below the plane. To see wildlife, you'll need to join a boat tour. We don't land on Antarctica for environmental reasons.

**Photography**

Feel free to take photos! We even have fun photo opportunities where you can wear Antarctic cold-weather clothes.

Fog can suddenly appear over a hill, and hidden ice beneath the snow can cause you to lose control. A car coming towards you may suddenly skid across the road. To drive safely on icy roads, follow these two basic rules. First, drive smoothly and avoid sudden movements, like turning the wheel, pressing the brakes, or speeding up. Imagine you're driving with a cup of hot coffee next to you - drive carefully so you wouldn't spill it. Second, be aware of what might happen ahead. When there's a lot of ice, you need to look further down the road. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be going faster than you think. Generally, double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, triple it on snowy roads, and quadruple it on icy roads. Stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble."

In 1750, Henry Fielding started paying a group of people to stop thieves. They were like police officers and were called the 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London was getting too big and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force was established with 3000 officers. Most officers walked, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police are well paid, and officers who still ride horses get paid even more than the others.'

I made the following changes to simplify the text:

* Simplified vocabulary: replaced "starting to get bigger" with "grew bigger", "very dirty" with "dirty", "poor" with "many people were poor", "stop thieves" with "stop thieves" (no change needed), "worked near Bow Street" with "worked near Bow Street" (no change needed), "police officers" with "police officers" (no change needed), "the city was very big" with "the city was getting too big", "for the few police officers who still ride horses, the pay is even better than for the others" with "officers who still ride horses get paid even more than the others" (shortened and simplified the sentence structure).

'ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you'll reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes over, and thousands of Canadian fishermen visit every weekend. To stay warm and comfortable, you need to wear light but warm clothing, including extra socks, gloves, thin sweaters, and a snow suit. Catching fish is easy, Bob explains. First, you break the ice and make a small hole. Next, you attach a fishing line with some bread on it and lower it into the hole. When a fish eats the bread, you pull the line up. The fish are usually 10-20 centimeters long. Some people enjoy eating them, but I prefer to have a snack like chocolate after catching a few. Today, I caught 25! It's a fun sport, and you can meet friendly people here.'

There are two types of black bears: one lives in North America and the other in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are black; they can also be dark brown or reddish brown. The black and white panda bear, native to China, is a popular species. Unfortunately, there are not many pandas left in the forest because it's hard to find food."

"CROCODILES Crocodiles can be found in warm and tropical areas, such as Africa, South America, and Australia. They mostly live in slow-moving water, but they can swim quickly and even move on land. You often see them together in large groups. They eat a wide variety of food, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat larger animals or humans. There are over ten different types of crocodiles. All of them have very sharp teeth. They lose these teeth, but grow new ones quickly. Crocodiles are usually around 3.5 metres long, but some can be much bigger. They can live for a long time, with the oldest one in a zoo living for 66 years."

'History of Air Travel

In 1783, two French brothers built the first balloon that carried people into the air. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers in the United States built the first plane with an engine and flew in it. The US Post Office started the first airmail service in 1918. Over the next thirty years, aeroplanes underwent significant changes. In the 1950s, planes became much faster with the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, Concorde, a supersonic passenger plane, was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, flying at 2500 kilometres per hour. This means that a journey from London to New York now takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by plane, and it's hard to imagine a world without them.'

The audience members would often eat, chat with their friends, walk around, and sometimes even throw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same place, near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play or learn about life in the 17th century.'
